column1: 180937.0,237901,2145-02-15 07:03:00,Physician ,Physician Resident Progress Note,"TITLE: CCU Progress Note
- Vagaled when sheath pulled - dropped pressure, responded to pressors
- Unable to tolerate HD for low BPs so switched to CVVH
- On dopamine for pressure support with good effect
- Extremely poor arterial access so no Aline was placed. Will consider
groin line with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3213**] in the AM
- ABG overnight from L arm and has mixed venous and arterial blood from
Changes to medical and family history: none
Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
Review of systems: unable to obtain
RSBI Deferred: PEEP > 10, FiO2 > 60%, Hemodynamic Instability
Gen: WD elderly female intubated and sedated.
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no
pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa.
Neck: Supple with elevated JVP to earlobe.
CV: RRR, normal S1, S2. Distant heart tones, No m/r/g appreciated. No
thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4.
Chest: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were
Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. No abdominial bruits.
Ext: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. R femoral PA line in place
Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.
Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 1+ DP/PT + dopplerable, L PT faint doppler
Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:13.7/28.7/1.2, CK / CKMB /
Troponin-T:842/159/4.00, ALT / AST:50/188, Alk Phos / T Bili:105/0.4,
Mono:2.7 %, Eos:0.2 %, Lactic Acid:2.9 mmol/L, Albumin:3.1 g/dL,
LDH:792 IU/L, Ca++:9.3 mg/dL, Mg++:1.4 mg/dL, PO4:3.2 mg/dL
80y.o F with a PMH of ESRD on HD, CVA, diastolic CHF now admitted after
witnessed PEA arrest in the ED. Cath showed stenotic RCA. PCWP was
45mmHg. RCA was stented and hemodynamics improved with PCI. Transferred
to the CCU on pressors initially on HD, then on CVVH due to
hypothermia, hyperkalemia, hypovolemia, and hypoxia. Other etiologies
tamponade, toxins, thrombosis, tension pneumo, sepsis, severe CHF.  In
her, patient had hyperkalemia in the context of hemolysized specimen.
Patient had normal magnesium, was not hypothermic and was not
initially  hypoxic, intubated in the setting of PEA arrest rather than
because of low oxygenation.  Patient without tamponade physiology. Most
likely etiology thought to be secondary to cardiac ischemia.  Other
possibilities is acute sepsis, there is possibility of aspiration vs.
multifocal pneumonia on chest x-ray. Would consider PE also on the
differential but less likely given positive enzymes. The patient
presented with complaints of N/V, diarrhea and became bradycardic
followed by PEA arrest. Pt regained rhythm with epi/atropine X2.
Hyperkalemia was treated with kayexelate. No clear acidosis prior to
arrest on labs, glucose 129. The patient was found to have CK elevated
to 452 with MBI 9.7 and troponin 3.74. In cath lab the patient was
found to have markedly elevated PCWP to 45mmg Hg and mean PA to 46 mm
Hg. Hemodynamics improved with RCA stenting. Pt now s/p RCA PCI.
- Continue ASA 325mg PO daily, Plavix 75mg PO daily
- Continue supportive management with mechanical ventilation
- Given short duration of arrest approx 8 min with return of spont
movement in cath lab, Artic Sun protocol was deferred
- trend cardiac enzymes, consider going back to cath lab today
- Monitor lytes, CVVH for volume overload
# Multifocal Pulmonary infiltrate - CT demonstrated a diffuse
consolidation of the lung bases with bronchial infiltration.
- given unclear precipitant of PEA arrest, pt not clearly hypoxic on
presentation but with initial elevated O2 requirement (FIO2 70%), CT
with evidence of bilateral pulmonary infiltrates
- Vanc/Zosyn for now, got ID approval
- consider dedicated chest CT when patient stable
#. ESRD on CVVH - Given markedly elevated PCWP and hyperkalemia, the
patient was urgently dialyzed post-cath however patient was unable to
tolerated standard HD due to hypotension so changed to CVVH.
-          consider changing back to HD when tolerated
-          Repeat TTE today to further evaluate systolic function and
-          Hold metoprolol and losartan for now given unstable BP.
#. Hypertension - holding outpatient regimen of losartan, metoprolol,
#. Orthostatic hypotension - on midodrine as outpatient after HD, will
NPO until after cath, will start tube feeds afterwards
#. Access: R PA catheter, attempt a-line today if tolerated
#. PPx: PPI, bowel regimen, heparin SC
On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
agree with the above note and plans.
I would add the following remarks:
nothing to add, agree with above
nothing to add, agree with above
nothing to add, agree with above
Above discussed extensively with family member, next of [**Doctor First Name **] or health
Total time spent on patient care: 60 minutes of critical care time.

------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) 3213**] [**Name (NI) 862**]  on:[**2145-2-16**]

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), Cerebrovascular Accident (CVA), and diastolic Congestive Heart Failure (CHF). She was admitted after a witnessed Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA) arrest in the Emergency Department (ED). The patient underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stenting of the right coronary artery (RCA) and hemodynamics improved.

The patient has been experiencing hypotension, and HD was switched to Continuous Venovenous Hemofiltration (CVVH) due to intolerance. She is currently on dopamine for pressure support and has a poor arterial access, which may require a groin line.
The patient has several medical complications, including:
2. Multifocal pulmonary infiltrate, which was diagnosed on computed tomography (CT) scan.
3. ESRD on CVVH, which was urgently dialyzed post-cath but could not tolerate standard HD due to hypotension.
4. Chronic diastolic CHF, which is being managed with repeat TTE and holding of metoprolol and losartan.
5. Hypertension, which is being managed by holding outpatient regimen of losartan, metoprolol, and nifedipine.
6. Hypothyroidism, which is being managed with synthroid.
7. Orthostatic hypotension, which is being managed with midodrine as an outpatient.
8. FEN (Foley catheter not present), which is being managed with NPO and tube feeds afterwards.
9. Access: R PA catheter, attempt A-line today if tolerated.
10. PPx: PPI, bowel regimen, heparin SC.

The patient is being managed with supportive care, including mechanical ventilation, CVVH, and medications. The plan is to continue ASA and Plavix, monitor lytes, and consider going back to the cath lab today.
Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Hypotension and cardiac arrest due to the patient's history of PEA arrest and chronic CHF.
2. Respiratory failure due to the patient's pulmonary infiltrates and need for mechanical ventilation.
3. Sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome due to the patient's immunocompromised state and history of CVA.
4. Cardiac tamponade and pericarditis due to the patient's history of cardiac arrest and PCI.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation due to the patient's history of CHF and need for anticoagulation.
6. Infection and sepsis due to the patient's urinary catheter and need for dialysis.
The patient's code status is FULL, and her disposition is pending clinical improvement."

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), Chronic Vascular Accident (CVA), and diastolic Congestive Heart Failure (CHF). She presented with a witnessed Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA) arrest in the Emergency Department (ED) and was found to have a stenotic Right Coronary Artery (RCA) on cardiac catheterization. The patient was stabilized with RCA stenting and transferred to the Cardiovascular Intensive Care Unit (CCU) on pressors.
The patient's current condition is as follows:
* Vital signs: Temperature 36.1Â°C, Heart rate 112 bpm, Blood pressure 115/57 mmHg, Respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, SpO2 100%.

* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous pressure (CVP) 34 mmHg, Pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) 28 mmHg, Cardiac output (CO) 3.5 L/min, Cardiac index (CI) 2.1 L/min/m2, Mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) 60%.
* Laboratory results: White blood cell count (WBC) 17.7 x 10^9/L, Hematocrit (Hct) 38%, Platelet count (Plt) 262 x 10^9/L, Creatinine (Cr) 4.8 mg/dL, Troponin-T 4.70 ng/mL, Lactic acid 2.9 mmol/L.
* Medications: Fentanyl 50 mcg/hour, Midazolam 2 mg/hour, Dopamine 8 mcg/kg/min, ASA 325 mg PO daily, Plavix 75 mg PO daily, Vanc/Zosyn for antibiotic coverage.
* Hypertension, which is being managed with antihypertensive medications.
* Chronic diastolic CHF, which is being managed with diuretics and vasodilators.
* ESRD on CVVH, which is being managed with continuous venovenous hemofiltration.
* Multifocal pulmonary infiltrate, which is being managed with antibiotics and bronchodilators.
* Hyperkalemia, which was treated with kayexelate.
The patient's potential medical complications include:
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalance and cardiac ischemia.
* Sepsis due to multi-organ dysfunction and antibiotic-resistant infections.
* Respiratory failure due to pneumonia and pulmonary edema.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to stress ulcer and anticoagulation therapy.
* Neurological complications due to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and sepsis.
The patient's plan of care includes:
* Continue ASA 325 mg PO daily and Plavix 75 mg PO daily.
* Continue supportive management with mechanical ventilation.
* Monitor electrolytes and CVVH for volume overload.
* Trend cardiac enzymes and consider going back to the cath lab today.
* Monitor for signs of cardiac arrhythmias and sepsis.
* Consider dedicated chest CT when the patient is stable.
* Repeat TTE today to further evaluate systolic function and evidence of diastolic dysfunction.
* Hold metoprolol and losartan for now given unstable BP.
* Hold midodrine for now due to hypotension.
* Attempt to place an arterial line today if tolerated.
* Continue prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP."

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), Cerebrovascular Accident (CVA), and diastolic Congestive Heart Failure (CHF). She was admitted after a witnessed Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA) arrest in the Emergency Department (ED). The patient underwent Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) and was found to have marked elevation of Pulmonary Capillary Wedge Pressure (PCWP) and Mean Pulmonary Artery Pressure (MPAP). She was transferred to the Cardiovascular Intensive Care Unit (CCU) on pressors initially on HD, then on Continuous Venovenous Hemofiltration (CVVH) due to hypotension.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated creatinine, potassium, and troponin levels, indicating cardiac ischemia and possible acute coronary syndrome. The patient also has a multifocal pulmonary infiltrate on computed tomography (CT) scan, which may be related to the PEA arrest or underlying chronic CHF.
* Continue supportive management with mechanical ventilation
* Given short duration of arrest, Artic Sun protocol was deferred
* Monitor lytes, CVVH tonight for hyperkalemia and volume overload

1. Cardiac ischemia and acute coronary syndrome: The patient's elevated troponin levels and PCWP suggest cardiac ischemia and possible acute coronary syndrome. Monitoring of cardiac enzymes and echocardiogram is essential to assess cardiac function.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient's multifocal pulmonary infiltrate on CT scan and requirement for mechanical ventilation suggest respiratory failure. Monitoring of oxygen saturation and pulmonary function tests is essential to assess respiratory function.
3. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia may be related to the PEA arrest or underlying kidney disease. Monitoring of potassium levels and CVVH therapy is essential to manage hyperkalemia.
4. Volume overload: The patient's requirement for CVVH suggests volume overload. Monitoring of fluid status and CVVH therapy is essential to manage volume overload.

5. Infection: The patient's multifocal pulmonary infiltrate on CT scan and requirement for antibiotic therapy suggest possible infection. Monitoring of blood cultures and antibiotic therapy is essential to manage infection.

6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's requirement for mechanical ventilation and possible gastrointestinal bleeding is a concern. Monitoring of gastrointestinal bleeding and management of bleeding is essential.
1. Monitor cardiac enzymes and echocardiogram to assess cardiac function.
2. Monitor oxygen saturation and pulmonary function tests to assess respiratory function.
3. Monitor potassium levels and CVVH therapy to manage hyperkalemia.
4. Monitor fluid status and CVVH therapy to manage volume overload.
5. Monitor blood cultures and antibiotic therapy to manage infection.
6. Monitor gastrointestinal bleeding and manage bleeding if necessary."

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old female with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, Chronic Diastolic Heart Failure, and a recent Cardiac Arrest. She was intubated and transferred to the Cardiac Care Unit (CCU) due to hypotension.

* Cardiac: She has worsening left ventricular systolic dysfunction with a reduced ejection fraction (EF) of 40% from 70%. She has also developed severe hypokinesis of the distal 2/3rds of the anterior septum and anterior walls, distal inferior and apical walls.
* Respiratory: She has multifocal pulmonary infiltrate on chest x-ray and is being ventilated with a FiO2 of 40% and PEEP of 5.
* Hemodynamic: She is still requiring dopamine to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) in the 60s.
* Renal: She is on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) due to hypotension and hyperkalemia.
* Infections: She has elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
* Other: She has a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, and orthostatic hypotension.
Potential medical complications that may arise:
1. Cardiac: Further deterioration of cardiac function, development of cardiac arrhythmias, or cardiac tamponade.
2. Respiratory: Pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), or respiratory failure.
3. Renal: Acute kidney injury (AKI), hyperkalemia, or acidosis.
4. Infections: Sepsis, septic shock, or multi-organ failure.
5. Hemodynamic: Hypotension, shock, or cardiac arrest.
6. Gastrointestinal: Gastrointestinal bleeding, ileus, or bowel obstruction.
1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust therapy accordingly.
2. Wean the patient off pressors and ventilator support as tolerated.
3. Consider repeat cardiac catheterization to address LAD stenosis.
4. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics and monitor for signs of infection.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolytes, particularly potassium and phosphorus, and adjust therapy accordingly.
6. Consider changing back to standard hemodialysis when the patient's hemodynamics improve.
7. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust caloric intake accordingly.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy accordingly."

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old female with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), Cerebrovascular Accident (CVA), and diastolic Congestive Heart Failure (CHF). She was admitted after a witnessed Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA) arrest in the Emergency Department (ED) and was found to have stenotic Right Coronary Artery (RCA) on cardiac catheterization. The patient underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and was transferred to the Cardiovascular Intensive Care Unit (CCU).
The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Cardiac: The patient has mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with severe hypokinesis of the distal 2/3rds of the anterior septum and anterior walls, distal inferior and apical walls. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 40%, previously 55%). There is moderate aortic valve stenosis (area 1.0cm2).
* Respiratory: The patient has multifocal pulmonary infiltrate with diffuse consolidation of the lung bases and bronchial infiltration on computed tomography (CT) scan.
* Renal: The patient has ESRD on HD, and was changed to continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) due to hypotension.
* Hemodynamic: The patient is requiring pressors to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) in the 60s.
Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:
+ Worsening of left ventricular systolic dysfunction
+ Increased risk of cardiac ischemia and infarction
+ Worsening of pulmonary infiltrate and consolidation
+ Development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Cardiac catheterization to treat left anterior descending (LAD) stenosis
* Monitor electrolytes and CVVH for volume overload
* Continue supportive management with mechanical ventilation
* Wean dopamine as tolerated to maintain MAPs > 60
* Consider reversal of non-functioning AV fistula to improve cardiac output
* Continue ASA 325mg PO daily and Plavix 75mg PO daily
The patient's family was updated, and tube feeds were held pending cardiac catheterization. The patient's code status is FULL, and her disposition is pending clinical improvement."

The patient is also experiencing multifocal pulmonary infiltrate, hypoxia, and hypertension.
* Worsening cardiac function: The patient's EF has decreased from 70% to 40%, which may indicate further cardiac damage or ongoing ischemia.
* Pressor dependence: The patient's requirement for pressors may indicate ongoing hypotension, which can lead to organ dysfunction or failure.

* Multifocal pulmonary infiltrate: The patient's CT scan shows diffuse consolidation of the lung bases with bronchial infiltration, which may indicate pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), or other pulmonary complications.
* Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to respiratory failure or other complications.
* ESRD on CVVH: The patient's CVVH may not be adequately controlling her fluid and electrolyte status, leading to complications such as volume overload or electrolyte imbalances.
* Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to cardiac arrhythmias or other complications.
* Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated WBC count may indicate sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction or failure.
* Pneumonia: The patient's multifocal pulmonary infiltrate may indicate pneumonia, which can lead to respiratory failure or other complications.
* Nausea and vomiting: The patient's nausea and vomiting may indicate gastrointestinal distress, which can lead to dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, or other complications.
* Diarrhea: The patient's diarrhea may indicate gastrointestinal distress or infection, which can lead to dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, or other complications.
Given the patient's complex medical status, it is essential to closely monitor her condition and adjust her treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage potential complications."

The patient has a number of comorbidities, including hypertension, hypothyroidism, and orthostatic hypotension. She is also taking a number of medications, including ASA, Plavix, synthroid, and midodrine.

3. Renal complications: The patient's requirement for CVVH and her history of ESRD on HD suggest that she may be at risk for further renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or worsening of her underlying kidney disease.

4. Infectious complications: The patient's requirement for broad-spectrum antibiotics and her history of PEA arrest suggest that she may be at risk for further infectious complications, such as sepsis or septic shock.

5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's requirement for tube feeds and her history of N/V, diarrhea, and abdominal tenderness suggest that she may be at risk for further gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.
1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust her medication regimen as necessary to optimize her cardiac output.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), CVA, and diastolic CHF. She presented with a witnessed PEA arrest in the Emergency Department (ED) and was resuscitated with epinephrine and atropine. She was found to have markedly elevated PCWP and mean PA pressure, and hemodynamics improved with RCA stenting.
The patient has multiple comorbidities, including hypertension, hypothyroidism, and orthostatic hypotension. She is currently on mechanical ventilation, CVVH, and is receiving supportive care.
Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalances or medication interactions
* Cardiac failure exacerbation due to continued hypertension or hypotension
* Ischemic heart disease due to reduced cardiac output or coronary artery disease
* Pneumonia or aspiration due to prolonged intubation and immobility
* Respiratory failure due to inadequate oxygenation or ventilation
* Acute kidney injury due to CVVH or medication toxicity
* Chronic kidney disease progression due to continued hypertension or hypotension
* Cerebral edema or herniation due to increased ICP or hypotension
* Seizures or status epilepticus due to electrolyte imbalances or medication interactions
* Sepsis or septic shock due to bacteremia or pneumonia
* Catheter-related infections due to poor catheter care or colonization
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to prolonged immobility or medication interactions
* Pancreatitis or cholecystitis due to medication toxicity or gallstone disease

The patient's current medications include ASA, Plavix, metoprolol, losartan, nifedipine, and synthroid. The patient's laboratory results show elevated cardiac enzymes, troponin, and CK, indicating cardiac damage. The patient's electrocardiogram shows ST elevation in the anterior leads, consistent with myocardial infarction.

The patient's plan of care includes continuing ASA and Plavix, supportive management with mechanical ventilation, and monitoring of cardiac enzymes and electrolytes. The patient will also undergo a repeat TTE to evaluate systolic function and diastolic dysfunction."

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old female with a past medical history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), CVA, and diastolic CHF. She was admitted after a witnessed PEA arrest in the emergency department (ED). The patient was found to have stenotic RCA, which was stented during PCI, and hemodynamics improved.

The patient's current condition is critical, with ongoing hypotension requiring dopamine infusion to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) in the 60s. She has a history of hyperkalemia, which was treated with kayexelate. The patient also has elevated cardiac enzymes, including CK and troponin.
The patient has a number of potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, with mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction and severe hypokinesis of the distal 2/3rds of the anterior septum and anterior walls. This can lead to further cardiac deterioration, including heart failure, cardiogenic shock, and arrhythmias.

2. Respiratory complications: The patient is mechanically ventilated, which increases the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and other respiratory complications. The patient also has a multifocal pulmonary infiltrate on CT scan, which may indicate pneumonia or other respiratory infections.

3. Renal complications: The patient is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH), which is a high-risk modality for renal injury. The patient may be at risk for acute kidney injury (AKI) or further deterioration of her renal function.

4. Infection complications: The patient has a central venous catheter and an arterial line, which increases the risk of infection. The patient also has a history of hyperkalemia, which may be a sign of underlying electrolyte disturbances or other metabolic disorders.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of nausea and vomiting, which may indicate gastrointestinal distress or other complications.
1. Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) to manage her renal function and electrolyte disturbances.
2. Mechanical ventilation to support her respiratory function.
3. Dopamine infusion to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) in the 60s.
4. Antibiotics to treat potential infections, including pneumonia or sepsis.
5. Further cardiac evaluation, including repeat echocardiogram, to assess her cardiac function and potential need for further intervention.
6. Monitoring of her cardiac enzymes and electrolyte levels to detect any changes or complications.
7. Consideration of further interventions, including repeat PCI or other cardiac procedures, to improve her cardiac function.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for a number of medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications and improve her clinical outcomes."

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of ESRD on HD, CVA, and diastolic CHF, who presented with a witnessed PEA arrest in the ED. She was intubated and transferred to the CCU, where she underwent PCI of the RCA and stenting of the LAD. Her hemodynamics improved, but she still requires pressors. The patient has a decreased ejection fraction (EF) of 40%, and her troponin levels are elevated. She has a multifocal pulmonary infiltrate on chest x-ray and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
* Worsening of CHF due to decreased EF
* Acute kidney injury due to CVVH
* Potential for bleeding complications due to anticoagulation therapy
1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust treatment accordingly.
2. Consider repeat cardiac catheterization to address the LAD stenosis.
3. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for the multifocal pulmonary infiltrate.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust dialysis therapy as needed.
5. Continue to manage the patient's electrolyte imbalance and fluid overload.
6. Consider reversal of the non-functioning AV fistula to improve cardiac output.
7. Wean the patient off pressors as tolerated and monitor for signs of hypotension.
8. Consider a pressure support trial following cardiac catheterization.
9. Monitor the patient's glycemic control and adjust insulin therapy as needed.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's WBC count and adjust antibiotic therapy as needed."

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on Hemodialysis (HD), Chronic Diastolic Heart Failure (CHF), and Chronic Hypertension. He was admitted after a witnessed Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA) arrest in the Emergency Department (ED). He underwent two cardiac catheterizations, with stenting of the Right Coronary Artery (RCA) and Left Anterior Descending (LAD) arteries. He is currently in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a diagnosis of cardiogenic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and multifocal pulmonary infiltrate.
Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he may experience further decline in cardiac output, leading to worsening shock.
2. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's oxygenation is compromised, and he may experience further decline in oxygenation, leading to respiratory failure.
3. Multifocal pulmonary infiltrate: The patient has a diffuse consolidation of the lung bases with bronchial infiltration, which may lead to further respiratory compromise.
4. ESRD on CVVH: The patient is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH), which may lead to complications such as hypotension, bleeding, and infection.
5. Chronic diastolic CHF: The patient's chronic heart failure may worsen, leading to further decline in cardiac function and increased risk of cardiovascular events.
6. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, which may lead to further cardiovascular complications.
7. Orthostatic hypotension: The patient may experience further decline in blood pressure upon standing, leading to dizziness and syncope.
8. FEN tube feeds: The patient's tube feeds may be discontinued or interrupted, leading to malnutrition and dehydration.
1. Controlling cardiogenic shock with dopamine and pressors.
2. Managing hypoxic respiratory failure with pressure support and weaning sedation.
3. Treating multifocal pulmonary infiltrate with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
4. Continuing CVVH for now, with consideration of changing to hemodialysis when tolerated.
5. Holding outpatient medications such as metoprolol and losartan due to unstable blood pressure.
6. Considering repeat echocardiogram to assess cardiac function.
7. Continuing glycemic control and nutrition management.
8. Monitoring for potential complications such as bleeding, infection, and cardiovascular events."

1. Shock: The patient is suspected to have a mixture of cardiogenic and septic shock, requiring pressors and continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).

3. Multifocal Pulmonary Infiltrate: The patient has a diffuse consolidation of the lung bases with bronchial infiltration, and is on broad-spectrum antibiotics.
4. ESRD on CVVH: The patient was urgently dialyzed post-cath, but was unable to tolerate standard HD due to hypotension, and was changed to CVVH.
5. Chronic Diastolic CHF: The patient has mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size, and mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction.

8. Orthostatic Hypotension: The patient has a history of orthostatic hypotension, and is currently holding his midodrine medication due to blood pressure issues.

* Consideration of dedicated chest CT when the patient is stable
* Holding metoprolol and losartan for now due to blood pressure issues
* Repeat echo after the patient is weaned off pressors
* Consider changing back to HD when the patient is able to tolerate it."

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old female with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), Chronic Diastolic Heart Failure (CHF), and Cerebrovascular Accident (CVA). She was admitted after a witnessed Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA) arrest in the Emergency Department (ED). The patient underwent two cardiac catheterizations with placement of two stents to the Left Anterior Descending (LAD) artery.

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on pressure support trial with a pressure of 5 cmH2O. She has a mild diffuse consolidation of the lung bases with bronchial infiltration on computed tomography (CT) scan.

* Cardiovascular: The patient has a history of diastolic CHF with mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy and moderate aortic valve stenosis. She has a high-normal pulmonary artery systolic pressure.
* Renal: The patient is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) due to hypotension and inability to tolerate standard HD.
* Hemodynamic: The patient is on dopamine to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) > 60 mmHg.
* Neurological: The patient is sedated and has a history of CVA.
* Infection: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) with a GNR in her urine culture.
* Anemia: The patient has a low hemoglobin level and is being transfused with packed red blood cells (PRBCs).
* Hypothyroidism: The patient is being treated with levothyroxine (synthroid).
Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she is still intubated and on pressure support. There is a risk of reintubation if she is extubated too early.
* Cardiac failure: The patient has a history of diastolic CHF and may experience further cardiac decompensation if her hemodynamics are not optimized.
* Renal failure: The patient is on CVVH, but there is a risk of further renal deterioration if her blood pressure is not controlled.
* Infection: The patient has a UTI and may develop further infections if her immune system is compromised.
* Bleeding: The patient has a history of CVA and may be at risk of bleeding if she is anticoagulated.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may not be adequately controlled, leading to further complications.
The patient's plan of care includes:
* Continuation of CVVH until her blood pressure is stable.
* Trial of extubation today if her respiratory status improves.
* Continuation of broad-spectrum antibiotics for her UTI.
* Consideration of dedicated chest CT when the patient is stable.
* Monitoring of her hemoglobin level and transfusion as needed.
* Management of her hypertension and hypothyroidism.
* Evaluation of her cardiac function and consideration of further interventions if necessary."

The patient's liver function is also abnormal, with elevated alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase levels.
The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute and a tidal volume of 450 mL. The patient is receiving dopamine infusions to support blood pressure.
The patient's physical examination reveals a well-nourished individual with no acute distress. The patient's neurological examination is abnormal, with decreased responsiveness and no movement.
Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac catheterization procedure and elevated troponin levels may indicate cardiac injury, which can lead to complications such as arrhythmias, cardiac tamponade, or cardiogenic shock.

2. Renal complications: The patient's elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels may indicate acute kidney injury, which can lead to complications such as electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, or anemia.
3. Liver complications: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may indicate liver injury, which can lead to complications such as coagulopathy, jaundice, or liver failure.

4. Respiratory complications: The patient's mechanical ventilation and elevated respiratory rate may indicate respiratory failure, which can lead to complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, respiratory acidosis, or respiratory failure.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's decreased responsiveness and no movement may indicate neurological injury, which can lead to complications such as seizures, stroke, or brain death.
6. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate levels may indicate sepsis, which can lead to complications such as organ failure, shock, or death.

7. Venous thromboembolism: The patient's prolonged ICU stay and immobility may increase the risk of venous thromboembolism, which can lead to complications such as pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and medical complications."

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of ESRD on HD, CVA, and diastolic CHF, who was admitted after a witnessed PEA arrest in the ED. He underwent PCI with stenting of the RCA and LAD, and has since been weaned off pressors. The patient remains comatose and has a fever of 101.2Â°C, with a recent temperature spike. He has a diffuse consolidation of the lung bases with bronchial infiltration on CT scan, and is on broad-spectrum antibiotics. The patient has a UTI, anemia, and hypothyroidism, and is being managed for chronic diastolic CHF.

1. Anoxic brain injury: The patient's ongoing coma in spite of being off sedation and with good BP and uremic control raises concerns for anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure is improving, but he remains on pressure support and is at risk for respiratory complications.
3. Sepsis: The patient's fever, diffuse consolidation of the lung bases, and UTI suggest sepsis, which may worsen his condition.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD/Ischemia and recent PCI with stenting of the RCA and LAD puts him at risk for cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is not well-explained by his recent blood transfusion, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may be contributing to his decreased mental status and needs to be monitored and managed.
7. Orthostatic hypotension: The patient's history of orthostatic hypotension may be exacerbated by his recent blood transfusion and needs to be monitored.
8. UTI: The patient's UTI needs to be managed and monitored to prevent complications.
9. Chronic diastolic CHF: The patient's chronic diastolic CHF needs to be managed and monitored to prevent decompensation.
10. Access site complications: The patient's access site needs to be monitored for complications, such as bleeding or infection."

The patient is a 80-year-old male with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on Hemodialysis (HD), Cerebrovascular Accident (CVA), and Diastolic Heart Failure (CHF). He was admitted after a witnessed Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA) arrest in the Emergency Department (ED). The patient underwent cardiac catheterization with stenting of the Right Coronary Artery (RCA) and Left Anterior Descending (LAD) artery. He was initially on pressors and HD, but was transitioned to Continuous Venovenous Hemofiltration (CVVH) due to hypotension. The patient's hemodynamics have improved, and pressors were discontinued. He remains comatose.
The patient's current status is as follows:
* Hemodynamics: Blood pressure is stable, and cardiac function is improving.
* Respiratory: The patient is on pressure support ventilation with a tidal volume of 375 mL and a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. The SpO2 is 99%.
* Neurologic: The patient remains comatose, with no response to commands.
* Infection: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) with a Gram-Negative Rod (GNR) in the urine culture.
* Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 8.0 g/dL, and he was transfused with 1 unit of packed red blood cells (PRBCs).
* Other: The patient has a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, and orthostatic hypotension.
1. Anoxic Brain Injury: The patient's ongoing coma and lack of response to commands may be indicative of an anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest.
2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he may still be at risk for hypoxic respiratory failure.
3. UTI: The patient has a UTI with a GNR in the urine culture, which may require further treatment and monitoring.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may require further transfusions and monitoring.
5. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's history of CHF and cardiac catheterization may increase his risk for cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.

6. Pulmonary Complications: The patient's history of chronic diastolic CHF and recent cardiac catheterization may increase his risk for pulmonary complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

7. Renal Complications: The patient's history of ESRD and recent cardiac catheterization may increase his risk for renal complications, such as acute kidney injury (AKI) or chronic kidney disease (CKD).
1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamics and respiratory status closely.
2. Consider a head CT to rule out anoxic brain injury.
3. Continue antibiotics for the UTI and monitor for signs of sepsis.
4. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider further transfusions as needed.
5. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension and hypothyroidism.
6. Consider a trial of extubation once the patient's respiratory status improves.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular and renal status closely."

She remains comatose and is being managed for acute ischemia, hypoxic respiratory failure, coma, shock, and multifocal pulmonary infiltrate.
1. Anoxic Brain Injury: The patient's ongoing coma may be due to anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's multifocal pulmonary infiltrate may progress to pneumonia, which could worsen her respiratory status.
3. UTI: The patient's GNR-positive urine culture may indicate a urinary tract infection, which could lead to sepsis.
4. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen if not properly managed.
5. Orthostatic Hypotension: The patient's history of orthostatic hypotension may be exacerbated by her recent hypotensive episode.
6. Chronic Diastolic CHF: The patient's chronic diastolic CHF may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further cardiac compromise.
7. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further cardiac compromise.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further compromise of her cardiac function.
9. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding may be exacerbated by her recent use of anticoagulants.
10. Infection: The patient's recent use of antibiotics and her ongoing comatose state may increase her risk of infection."

The patient is a 80-year-old female with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), CVA, and diastolic CHF. She was admitted after a witnessed PEA arrest in the ED and underwent cardiac catheterization with stenting of the RCA and LAD. She has been in the ICU for several days and has made significant improvements in her hemodynamics and respiratory status. However, she remains comatose and has not responded to pain stimuli.
1. Anoxic Brain Injury: The patient's prolonged coma and lack of response to pain stimuli suggest the possibility of anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri- and post-PEA arrest.
2. Shock: The patient's initial shock, which was treated with CVVH and pressors, has resolved, but there is still a risk of recurrent shock due to her underlying cardiogenic and septic shock.
3. Multifocal Pulmonary Infiltrate: The patient's CT scan on admission demonstrated a diffuse consolidation of the lung bases with bronchial infiltration, which may be contributing to her hypoxia.
4. UTI: The patient's urine culture grew GNR, which may be a source of sepsis and shock.

5. Chronic Diastolic CHF: The patient's repeat echo demonstrated mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size, but with moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, which may be contributing to her cardiogenic shock.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's chronic hypothyroidism may be contributing to her anemia and other systemic symptoms.
7. Orthostatic Hypotension: The patient's history of orthostatic hypotension may be contributing to her hypotension and shock.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be contributing to her fatigue, weakness, and other systemic symptoms.
1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamics and respiratory status closely.
2. Consider repeat head CT to rule out anoxic brain injury.
3. Continue to manage the patient's shock with CVVH and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
4. Consider dedicated chest CT to evaluate the patient's multifocal pulmonary infiltrate.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's urine output and consider changing antibiotics if the urine culture grows a different organism.
6. Consider repeat echo to evaluate the patient's chronic diastolic CHF.
7. Continue to manage the patient's hypothyroidism with synthroid.
8. Consider exchanging the patient's dialysis catheter if it is not functioning well.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's access site and consider exchanging the patient's dialysis catheter if it is not functioning well.
10. Consider the patient's code status and disposition pending clinical improvement."

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

* The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), CVA, and diastolic CHF, who was admitted after a witnessed PEA arrest in the Emergency Department (ED).
* The patient has undergone cardiac catheterization with stenting of the RCA and LAD, and has had a significant improvement in hemodynamics.
* The patient remains comatose and is currently on pressure support ventilation with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute and a tidal volume of 396 mL.

* The patient has a persistent fever despite removing the central line yesterday, with only positive cultures from the urine culture growing Enterobacter cloacae. The patient is currently on Zosyn for the urine infection.
* The patient has a history of CAD/Ischemia and is likely to have had a PEA arrest due to CAD/Ischemia.
* The patient has ongoing respiratory failure, with a RSBI of 125, and is being weaned from sedation.
* The patient has a coma, with concerns for anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest.

* The patient has a multifocal pulmonary infiltrate, with a CT scan demonstrating diffuse consolidation of the lung bases with bronchial infiltration. The patient is currently on broad-spectrum antibiotics and has a sputum culture growing yeast.
* The patient has a UTI, with a GNR growing in the urine culture, and is being treated with Zosyn.
* The patient has a history of chronic diastolic CHF, with a hold on metoprolol and losartan due to unstable blood pressure.
* The patient has anemia, with a drop in Hct, and is being transfused with PRBC.
* The patient has hypothyroidism, with a history of hypertension, and is being treated with synthroid.
* The patient has orthostatic hypotension, with a hold on midodrine due to blood pressure issues.
* The patient has a history of FEN tube feeds, with a hold on tube feeds this morning for possible extubation.
Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:
* Sepsis from the Enterobacter cloacae infection
* Respiratory failure due to the multifocal pulmonary infiltrate
* Anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest
* Cardiac complications due to CAD/Ischemia and the patient's history of chronic diastolic CHF
* Hemodynamic instability due to the patient's history of hypertension and orthostatic hypotension
* Gastrointestinal complications due to the patient's history of chronic diastolic CHF and the hold on metoprolol and losartan
* Nutritional deficiencies due to the patient's history of FEN tube feeds and the hold on tube feeds this morning.

I recommend that the patient be closely monitored for these potential complications and that the medical team consider a head CT to rule out anoxic brain injury, a dedicated chest CT to evaluate the multifocal pulmonary infiltrate, and a repeat echo to evaluate the patient's cardiac function."

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), Cerebral Vasculature Accident (CVA), and diastolic Congestive Heart Failure (CHF). He was admitted after a witnessed Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA) arrest in the Emergency Department (ED). He underwent cardiac catheterization with stenting of the Right Coronary Artery (RCA) and Left Anterior Descending (LAD) artery. He was initially on pressors and HD, but was transitioned to Continuous Venovenous Hemofiltration (CVVH) due to hypotension. His hemodynamics have improved, and pressors were discontinued.

* Fever: The patient's fever curve is trending down, and cultures from the femoral line are pending. He has a positive urine culture growing Enterobacter cloacae, which is pan-sensitive. He is being treated with Zosyn for the urine infection and will be transitioned to Cipro.
* PEA Arrest: The patient's PEA arrest is likely related to Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) and Ischemia. He is being managed with aspirin, statin, and Plavix.
* ESRD on HD/CVVH: His blood pressure has improved, and he will be transitioned to HD once his coronary artery intervention has stabilized.

* Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is improving, and he is being weaned off sedation. He is on pressure support with a tidal volume of 30 mL and is making low tidal volumes.
* Coma: The patient's mental status is improving, but he is still at risk for anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest.
* Shock: The patient's shock has resolved, and it is suspected to be a mixture of cardiogenic and septic shock.

* Multifocal Pulmonary Infiltrate: The patient has a diffuse consolidation of the lung bases with bronchial infiltration, which is improving on CMV and FiO2 weaned to 40%. Sputum cultures are growing only yeast.
* UTI: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Enterobacter cloacae, which is being treated with Zosyn and will be transitioned to Cipro.
* Chronic Diastolic CHF: The patient's chronic diastolic CHF is being managed with medications, and his blood pressure is being monitored.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is stable overnight.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism is being managed with Synthroid.
* Orthostatic Hypotension: The patient's orthostatic hypotension is being managed with midodrine as an outpatient, but it is being held for now due to blood pressure issues.
* FEN: The patient's tube feeds were held this morning for possible extubation.
* Access: The patient has a tunneled HD catheter in his right subclavian vein.
* PPx: The patient is receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Sepsis: The patient's UTI and positive cultures from the femoral line increase the risk of sepsis.
* Anoxic Brain Injury: The patient's PEA arrest and subsequent hypotension may have caused anoxic brain injury.
* Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if he is not extubated soon.
* Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's history of CAD and Ischemia increases the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
* Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of CVA and chronic diastolic CHF increases the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as constipation or diarrhea.
* Infection: The patient's positive cultures from the femoral line and urine increase the risk of infection."

The patient's condition has improved since her initial presentation, with her hemodynamics stabilizing and pressors discontinued. She remains comatose, and the team is concerned about the possibility of anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest.

The patient has a multifocal pulmonary infiltrate, with a diffuse consolidation of the lung bases on computed tomography (CT) scan. She is on broad-spectrum antibiotics and pressure support trial, with a target of weaning sedation and extubation.

The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) with a Gram-Negative Rod (GNR) in the urine culture, and is being treated with Zosyn. She also has chronic diastolic CHF, and her blood pressure is being closely monitored.

The patient's laboratory results show a drop in hematocrit (Hct) and a transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBC) was done. She also has hypothyroidism, and her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level is being monitored.

The patient's medical allergies include sulfonamides, erythromycin, atorvastatin, and colchicine, among others. She has a history of hypertension, anemia, and orthostatic hypotension, and is being treated with medications for these conditions.
The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism and need for medication make hypothyroidism a potential complication.
6. Anemia: The patient's drop in Hct and need for transfusion make anemia a potential complication.
7. Orthostatic hypotension: The patient's history of orthostatic hypotension and need for medication make orthostatic hypotension a potential complication.
8. DVT: The patient's history of CVA and need for prophylaxis make DVT a potential complication.

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on Hemodialysis (HD), Chronic Diastolic Heart Failure (CHF), and Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). She was admitted after a witnessed PEA arrest in the Emergency Department (ED) and underwent cardiac catheterization with stenting. She was initially on pressors and HD, then transitioned to Continuous Venovenous Hemofiltration (CVVH) due to hypotension. Her hemodynamics have improved, and pressors were discontinued.

The patient has been experiencing fever, with a trending-down fever curve since the femoral line was discontinued. The urine culture grew Enterobacter cloacae, which is pan-sensitive and will be transitioned to ciprofloxacin.
The patient is currently on Zosyn for urine infection and has been off vancomycin. She is also on aspirin, statin, and Plavix for CAD.

The patient has been experiencing respiratory failure, which is improving with CVVH and pressure support. She is being weaned off sedation and is on pressure support with a plan for trial of extubation this morning.
The patient has a coma, with improving mental status (MS), but concern for anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest.
The patient has also been experiencing shock, which is now resolved, suspected to be a mixture of cardiogenic and septic shock.
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged intubation.
2. Catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSI) due to the presence of central lines.
3. Worsening of anoxic brain injury from prolonged hypotension.
4. Development of chronic respiratory failure due to prolonged intubation.
5. Progression of CAD with potential for future cardiac events.
6. Development of sepsis or septic shock due to ongoing urinary tract infection.
7. Non-infectious complications of CVVH, such as bleeding or clotting disorders.
8. Development of chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to ongoing ESRD.
9. Hypothyroidism, which may require adjustment of synthroid dosing.
10. Orthostatic hypotension, which may require adjustment of midodrine dosing.

The patient's condition is improving, with stable hemodynamics and improving respiratory function. However, she remains at risk for various medical complications. The plan is to continue monitoring her condition closely and adjusting therapy as necessary. The patient will be continued on Zosyn for urine infection, and the plan is to transition to ciprofloxacin once the infection is cleared. The patient will also be continued on aspirin, statin, and Plavix for CAD.
The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is pending clinical improvement."

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, CVA, and diastolic CHF, who was admitted after a witnessed PEA arrest in the ED. She underwent cardiac catheterization with stenting and hemodynamics improved with PCI. She was transferred to the CCU on pressors initially on HD, then on Continuous Venovenous Hemofiltration (CVVH) due to hypotension.
* Hemodynamically stable with a blood pressure of 142/48 mmHg
* Respiratory support: intubated and on pressure support trial with a respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute
* Fever: trending down with a positive urine culture growing Enterobacter cloacae
* Urine infection: treated with Zosyn for 7 days
* PEA arrest: likely due to CAD/Ischemia s/p revascularization
* ESRD: on HD/CVVH, with a plan to restart low-dose metoprolol and losartan
* Altered mental status: improving, likely multifactorial related to meds, hypotension, and ICU delirium
* Orthostatic hypotension: held midodrine due to blood pressure issues
* FEN: tube feeds given overnight, held this morning for possible extubation, speech and swallow eval
Potential medical complications that can arise include:
* Respiratory failure: worsening respiratory rate, decreased SpO2, and increased RSBI
* Sepsis: due to the positive urine culture and fever
* Cardiac complications: CAD/Ischemia, cardiogenic shock, and arrhythmias
* Neurological complications: anoxic brain injury, delirium, and altered mental status
* Gastrointestinal complications: nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
* Hemodynamic instability: hypotension, hypertension, and cardiac arrest
The patient's plan for the day includes:
* Trial of extubation with anesthesia on call due to a difficult airway
* Completion of 7-day course of Zosyn for urine infection
* Monitoring of ESRD, respiratory failure, shock, and altered mental status
* Holding off on EPO given recent coronary artery intervention
* Speech and swallow eval for possible extubation"

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on pressure support trial with a Respiratory System Compliance (RSBI) of 68, indicating improved respiratory function. The plan is to trial extubation this morning.

* Cardiovascular: The patient's hemodynamics have improved, and pressors have been discontinued. She has a history of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) and Ischemia, and is likely to have CAD/Ischemia s/p revascularization.

* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, which is improving. She has a concern for anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest.
* Infection: The patient has a urine culture growing Enterobacter cloacae, and is on Zosyn for a 7-day course.
* Medications: The patient is taking aspirin, statin, and Plavix, and will continue these medications.
Potential medical complications that can arise include:
* Respiratory failure: The patient's RSBI is improving, but there is still a risk of respiratory failure if extubation is not successful.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of CAD and Ischemia, and there is a risk of cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
* Renal complications: The patient is on HD/CVVH, and there is a risk of renal complications such as acute kidney injury or worsening of ESRD.
* Neurological complications: The patient has altered mental status, and there is a risk of neurological complications such as anoxic brain injury or seizures.
* Infection: The patient has a urine culture growing Enterobacter cloacae, and there is a risk of infection spreading to other parts of the body.

Overall, the patient's condition is improving, but there are still several potential complications that can arise. Close monitoring and management of these complications will be necessary to ensure the patient's best possible outcome."

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), CVA, and diastolic CHF who was admitted after a witnessed PEA arrest in the ED. She underwent cardiac catheterization and was found to have stenotic RCA, which was stented. She was initially on pressors and HD, but later transitioned to continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) due to hypotension. Her hemodynamics have improved, and pressors were discontinued.

The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Enterobacter cloacae, which is sensitive to ciprofloxacin. She is currently on Zosyn and will transition to ciprofloxacin to complete a 10-day course.

The patient is also experiencing hypoxic respiratory failure, which is improving with CVVH and pressure support. She has a difficult airway due to a goiter and will have anesthesia on call for extubation.

Other medical issues include anemia, hypothyroidism, orthostatic hypotension, and chronic diastolic CHF. She is on several medications, including aspirin, statin, and Plavix, and has a tunneled HD catheter in her right subclavicular area.
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's difficult airway and prolonged intubation may increase her risk of developing VAP.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure may worsen if she is not properly managed.
3. Sepsis: The patient's UTI and recent cardiac catheterization may increase her risk of developing sepsis.
4. Anoxic brain injury: The patient's hypotension peri and post PEA arrest may have caused anoxic brain injury, which could lead to long-term cognitive impairment.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD and recent cardiac catheterization may increase her risk of developing cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or myocardial infarction.
6. Renal failure: The patient's ESRD and recent use of CVVH may increase her risk of developing renal failure.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's recent use of CVVH may increase her risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary.
2. Taper antibiotics to ciprofloxacin to complete a 10-day course.
3. Consider restarting metoprolol and losartan once blood pressure stabilizes.
4. Continue to manage the patient's ESRD, respiratory failure, and shock.
5. Monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent anoxic brain injury.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent cardiac complications.
7. Consider restarting tube feeds once the patient is extubated and her respiratory status has improved."

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, an 80-year-old female with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on Hemodialysis (HD), Cerebrovascular Accident (CVA), and diastolic Congestive Heart Failure (CHF), was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) after a witnessed Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA) arrest in the Emergency Department (ED). The patient underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stenting of the Right Coronary Artery (RCA) and Left Anterior Descending (LAD) arteries, which improved her hemodynamics.
The patient's current condition is as follows:
* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and a tidal volume of 339 mL. The patient's oxygen saturation is 97%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure is 142/48 mmHg, and her heart rate is 92 beats per minute. She is no longer on pressors.
* Neurological: The patient is sedated and has altered mental status, which is improving. She is at risk for anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest.
* Renal: The patient is on hemodialysis (HD) and has a urine output of 59 mL.
* Infectious: The patient has a urine culture growing Enterobacter cloacae, which is pan-sensitive. She is being treated with Zosyn, and will complete a 7-day course.
* Other: The patient has a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, and orthostatic hypotension.
Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and her tidal volume is 339 mL. She is at risk for respiratory failure if her oxygen saturation drops or if she develops pneumonia.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of CHF and has undergone PCI with stenting. She is at risk for cardiac complications such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.

* Neurological complications: The patient has altered mental status, which may be related to anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest. She is at risk for further neurological decline.
* Infection: The patient has a urine culture growing Enterobacter cloacae, and is at risk for further infections.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and is at risk for further bleeding or perforation.
The plan for the patient's care includes:
* Continue mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy
* Monitor the patient's respiratory rate and tidal volume
* Continue antibiotic therapy for the urine infection
* Monitor the patient's blood pressure and cardiac function
* Consider restarting metoprolol and losartan for the patient's CHF
* Monitor the patient's neurological status and consider further imaging or treatment if necessary
* Plan for trial of extubation this morning, with anesthesia on call due to the patient's difficult airway."

He has since undergone repeat cardiac catheterization with stenting of the LAD and has had progressive improvement in hemodynamics, with discontinuation of pressors. He was successfully extubated and is currently doing well.

1. Anoxic Brain Injury: The patient's altered mental status may be related to anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest, which could lead to long-term cognitive and neurological deficits.

3. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): The patient has a urine culture growing Enterobacter cloace, which may lead to a UTI if not treated appropriately.
4. Atelectasis: The patient's recent femoral line removal and need for encouragement to get out of bed may increase the risk of atelectasis, which could lead to respiratory compromise.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's history of hypothyroidism may require ongoing management, including thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
6. Orthostatic Hypotension: The patient's history of orthostatic hypotension may require ongoing management, including the use of midodrine as an outpatient.
7. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of CAD and CHF may increase the risk of cardiac complications, including arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.

8. Respiratory Complications: The patient's history of chronic diastolic CHF and recent respiratory failure may increase the risk of respiratory complications, including pneumonia, atelectasis, and respiratory failure.
9. Neurological Complications: The patient's history of CVA and recent PEA arrest may increase the risk of neurological complications, including stroke, seizure, and cognitive decline.
10. Infection: The patient's recent use of antibiotics and catheterization may increase the risk of infection, including bloodstream infection and catheter-related infection."

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), Coronary Artery Disease (CAD), and Chronic Diastolic Heart Failure (CHF). He was admitted after a witnessed Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA) arrest in the Emergency Department (ED) and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stenting of the Right Coronary Artery (RCA) and Left Anterior Descending (LAD) artery.
* The patient is extubated and doing well.
* He is on hemodialysis and has improved hemodynamics.
* He has a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Enterobacter cloacae, which is being treated with Zosyn for a 7-day course.
* He has a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, and orthostatic hypotension.
* He has a tunneled HD catheter in his right subclavicular area.
1. Anoxic Brain Injury: The patient's prolonged hypotension peri and post PEA arrest may have caused anoxic brain injury, which could lead to long-term cognitive impairment or disability.
2. ICU Delirium: The patient's altered mental status may be related to ICU delirium, which can be caused by the combination of medications, hypotension, and ICU environment.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's recent respiratory failure may recur if not properly managed, particularly with the presence of chronic diastolic CHF.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's CAD and CHF may lead to further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, congestive heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
5. Infection: The patient's UTI may spread to other parts of the body, leading to sepsis or septic shock.
6. Hemodialysis Complications: The patient's HD may be complicated by issues such as access site infection, bleeding, or hypotension.
7. Orthostatic Hypotension: The patient's history of orthostatic hypotension may worsen with the use of certain medications or during hemodialysis.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of bowel regimen and heparin subQ may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.
* Continue aspirin, statin, and Plavix as directed.
* Monitor the patient's hemodynamics and adjust medications as necessary.
* Manage the patient's ESRD, respiratory failure, shock, and altered mental status as directed.
* Complete the 7-day course of Zosyn for the UTI.
* Encourage the patient to get out of bed and chair to prevent atelectasis.
* Follow up with blood cultures and consider a speech and swallow evaluation.
* Consider restarting lopressor and adding captopril for chronic diastolic CHF.
* Hold midodrine for now due to blood pressure issues.
* Consider restarting tube feeds once the patient's respiratory status improves.
* Monitor the patient's dialysis catheter site for infection or bleeding."

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following summary can be drawn:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), CVA, and diastolic CHF. He was admitted after a witnessed PEA arrest in the Emergency Department (ED). He underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and stenting of the right coronary artery (RCA) and left anterior descending (LAD) arteries. He was initially on pressors and CVVH due to hypotension, but his hemodynamics have improved, and pressors were discontinued. He was successfully extubated and is now doing well.
1. ESRD on HD/CVVH: His blood pressure has improved, and he is now on HD.
2. Altered Mental Status: His mental status is improving, but he may have anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest.
3. Fever: His fever curve is trending down, and he has a positive urine culture growing Enterobacter cloacae. He is on Zosyn for a urine infection.
4. UTI: He has a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Enterobacter cloacae, and he will complete a 7-day course of Zosyn.
5. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: He has resolved his hypoxic respiratory failure and was extubated.
6. Cardiogenic Shock: He has resolved his cardiogenic shock.
7. Chronic Diastolic CHF: He has chronic diastolic CHF, and his treatment plan includes restarting lopressor and considering adding captopril.
8. Anemia: His anemia is stable, and there are no obvious hematomas from his recent catheterization.
9. Hypothyroidism: He is taking synthroid for his hypothyroidism.
10. Orthostatic Hypotension: He has orthostatic hypotension, which is being managed with midodrine as an outpatient.
Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Infection: The patient has a UTI and may be at risk for other infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs).
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of CAD and may be at risk for future cardiovascular events, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
3. Neurological complications: The patient may have anoxic brain injury from hypotension peri and post PEA arrest, which could lead to long-term cognitive or motor deficits.
4. Respiratory complications: The patient may be at risk for respiratory failure or pneumonia due to his chronic respiratory disease.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient may be at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to his chronic kidney disease and history of hypertension.
6. Hematological complications: The patient may be at risk for bleeding or thrombosis due to his anticoagulant therapy.
7. Metabolic complications: The patient may be at risk for metabolic acidosis or electrolyte imbalances due to his chronic kidney disease and history of hypertension.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but he is at risk for various medical complications. Close monitoring and management of his conditions are necessary to prevent or manage these complications."

7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of hypertension and diastolic CHF may increase her risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his underlying medical conditions to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal care."
